P052256.project_name: Rural Poverty Reduction Project - Minas Gerais

keywords.cdata: accountability, agricultural extension, analytical work, authorization, average level, beneficiaries, bureaucracy, CAS, Central government, Central government administration, citizen participation, citizens, civic engagement, civil society, community assets, community associations, community development, community groups, community level, community members, community organizations, community participation, Community Subprojects, Community-Driven Development, Competitive Bidding, consensus, Councils, Currency Unit, data, data collection, decentralization, decision-makers, decision-making, decisionmaking, development planning, development policies, development process, development programs, economic activity, Exchange Rate, execution, farm activities, farm income, Federal Government, financial capacity, financial institutions, Financial Management, financial resources, FISCAL, formal education, government administration, Governmental Organization, Human Development, impact assessment, impact evaluation, income generation, information campaigns, Institutional Development, institutional framework, institutional structure, land reform, learning, Lessons learned, lessons learnt, local decision making, local government, local governments, local level, management capacity, monitoring, Municipal agencies, municipal governments, municipality, Nations, natural resources, natural resources management, NGO, O & M, performance indicators, policy dialogue, political interference, Poverty Al

project_abstract.cdata: The objective of the Rural Poverty Reduction Project is to assist the State of Minas Gerais to reduce high levels of rural poverty by: (a) improving well being and incomes of the rural poor; (b) increasing the social capital of rural communities to organize collectively to meet own needs; (c) enhancing local governance by greater citizen participation and transparency in decision-making; and (d) fostering closer integration of development policies, programs and projects at the local level.  It consists of three components.  Component 1 (Community Subprojects) provides matching grants to rural community associations to finance approximately 1,860 socio-economic infrastructure and productive subprojects (up to US$50,000 each) identified by these groups as priority investments that will improve community well-being and benefit around 93,000 families.  Component 2 (Institutional Development) will finance technical assistance and training to increase capacity of implementing entities including municipal councils, community associations and the state technical unit.  Component 3 (Administration, Supervision, Monitoring and Evaluation) will finance incremental costs (excluding salaries) of project administration and coordination, including supervision, monitoring and impact evaluation.
